awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Unlocking Microbial Condensed Tannin Resistance Mechanisms: Scaling from Enzymes to Biomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Compounds known as condensed tannins (CTs) impact the ability of microbial communities to synthesize biofuels, detoxify industrial waste streams, perform critical carbon cycling in soils, and fuel nutrition in humans and animals. Despite their global importance, microbial responses to CTs are currently a mystery. This research project targets this substantial knowledge gap to identify the microorganisms and their enzymes that degrade CTs across a range of ecosystems. Beyond scientific advances, this project will also support significant curricular development in the introductory microbiology course at The Ohio State University. Through the development of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE), this project will allow hundreds of undergraduate student-scientists to perform authentic research; experiences shown to enhance scientific education and boost retention of students in scientific disciplines. This project will create a modified undergraduate laboratory class where CURE students participate in the discovery and classification of CT degrading microorganisms new to science, generating data that will be integrated into the research aims of this project. Additionally, the scientific data generated here will be transmitted more broadly to the scientific community via the production of an interactive, web-based bioinformatics platform. As part of the integrated research and educational objectives, this research will generate fundamental knowledge of CT-microbe interactions with direct applications to agricultural, industrial, and health resource management. 

Today the diversity of microorganisms, enzymes, and pathways mediating microbial CT degradation are currently unknown. The overarching goal of this research project is to test the central hypothesis that mechanisms for tolerance and degradation of CTs are widely encoded in microbial genomes across ecosystems, yet currently represent a cryptic microbial metabolism. This project tracks CT metabolism from organismal to ecosystem scales, identifying the enzymatic catalysts of organismal CT tolerance and degradation, the coordinated responses to CT perturbation in microbial communities, and the extent of CT metabolisms across ecosystems. Here, parallel isolate and community genomics paired to expression analyses and high-resolution CT metabolite data will elucidate the organisms, enzymes, and metabolisms mediating CT degradation and resistance. Outcomes from this research project include (1) knowledge of the microbial physiology and ecology of CTs, (2) discovery of novel degradative enzymes that are likely common to anaerobic microorganisms, (3) development of a CT library of biological and metabolite signatures resulting in the identification of microbial polyphenolics and their degradation products.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project aimed to uncover microbial mechanisms responsible for the degradation and tolerance of condensed tannins (CTs), which are plant phenolic compounds and the second most abundant plant polymer. CTs are present in ecosystems ranging from aquatic environments to soils, and even in the human body. These compounds play a key role in the global carbon cycle, yet their ecological role has often been misunderstood, particularly in anoxic environments. For instance, while CTs in human diets require microbial degradation in the gut to unlock health benefits, they were traditionally believed to inhibit microbial activity in soils, suppressing carbon and nitrogen cycling. This project sought to clarify the molecular mechanisms of microbial CT degradation, particularly in anoxic environments, where these processes were poorly understood.

Key Intellectual Merit: The project utilized advanced multi-omics approaches, including metabolomics, metaproteomics, and metagenomics, to significantly improve the understanding of microbial CT decomposition. The research led to 13 publications, five of which appeared in high-impact journals like Nature Microbiology and Nature Communications. The project's main achievements fall into four categories:

  1. Development of New Analytical Methods for CT Degradation: The team created open-source tools that integrate metabolomic data with genomic software, enabling the identification of genes and enzymes involved in CT degradation. These tools have become publicly available resources for researchers investigating CT metabolism.
  2. Advances in Microbial Genomic Annotation Software for Carbon Degradation: This project helped develop and scale the microbial genome annotation software, DRAM (Distilled Refined Annotation of Metabolisms). This tool has been widely adopted by the scientific community, cited over 500 times by 2020, linking microbial gene content with ecosystem functions.
  3. Paradigm Shift in Polyphenol Degradation in Soils: The project refuted the long-standing "enzyme latch hypothesis," which posited that polyphenols inhibit microbial activity in soils. The research revealed that microbes can degrade polyphenols in both laboratory and field-scale studies, suggesting that these compounds may actually enhance microbial carbon cycling in tannin-rich environments like thawing permafrost, where their degradation may exacerbate methane and carbon dioxide emissions.
  4. Broad Contributions to Understanding Carbon Cycling in Diverse Ecosystems: In addition to its findings in soils, this research also expanded knowledge of microbial carbon cycling in other environments, including agricultural systems, human cadavers, river sediments, and wetlands.

Broader Impacts: The project’s broader contributions include the development of tools and resources that are now widely available to the scientific community. One of the key products is the CAMPER (Curated Annotations for Microbial Polyphenol Enzymes and Reactions) database, which helps researchers identify microbial genes involved in CT degradation. This resource benefits a wide range of fields, from agriculture to human health.

The project also had a strong educational component. It supported the training and graduation of three female PhD students, two of whom have entered industry, while one has become an assistant professor. Additionally, the research led to the development of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE), which engaged students in hands-on research related to CT degradation and bioinformatics. This course was particularly impactful for students from underrepresented groups, providing them with opportunities to participate in real-world scientific discovery and helping to promote diversity in STEM. Two undergraduates involved in the course produced first-author publications, and all students from the course are now pursuing graduate degrees in microbiome sciences. Mentorship from Dr. Wrighton has continued for these students.

Collaborations with national institutions such as the Joint Genome Institute (JGI) and the Environmental Molecular Sciences Laboratory (EMSL) ensured that the research was widely disseminated and integrated into public scientific resources. Findings from this project were presented at over 25 oral and poster sessions and contributed to publicly accessible databases, supporting further research on microbial-plant interactions.

Project Summary. This NSF-funded project uncovered key microbial mechanisms involved in the degradation of condensed tannins (CTs), plant compounds essential to the global carbon cycle. By employing advanced techniques, the research identified novel enzymes and developed bioinformatics tools to study CT metabolism across ecosystems. The findings challenge long-held assumptions about CTs, revealing their active role in microbial carbon cycling, which has critical implications for climate change, particularly in thawing permafrost. The project significantly advanced scientific understanding created resources for broader community use, and contributed to workforce development by training the next generation of scientists.
